trading days immediately preceding the vesting dates. Column (e)&nbsp;reflects the market value of the 3,750 shares on the vesting dates and the cash equivalent of dividends paid on the vesting dates. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx66613_20"></A>Pension Benefits </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of the named executive officers is a participant in our tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and
is fully vested in his or her benefit under that plan. All, except Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso, were eligible to participate in our non-qualified defined benefit Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, or SERP. With the exception of Mr.&nbsp;West, whose
eligibility for a SERP benefit is described below, no benefit is payable under the SERP if the executive officer terminates employment prior to age 55 or if he or she does not have five years of service with the Company. As of December&nbsp;31,
2007, Mr.&nbsp;Lenny, Ms.&nbsp;Arline and Mr.&nbsp;Snyder were age 55 or older with five years of service. Mr.&nbsp;Lenny and Ms.&nbsp;Arline elected to retire at the end of 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The combination of the tax-qualified and SERP plans were designed to provide a benefit on retirement at or after reaching age 60 based on a joint and survivor annuity equal to 55% of final average compensation for an
executive officer with 15 or more years of service (reduced pro rata for each year of service under 15). Effective January&nbsp;1, 2007, the benefit payable under the SERP to an executive officer who was age 50 or over as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 was
reduced by 10%, and the benefit payable to an executive officer who had not attained age 50 as of January&nbsp;1, 2007, was reduced by 20%. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Final average
compensation is calculated as the sum of (i)&nbsp;the average of the highest three calendar years of base salary paid over the last five years of employment with the Company and (ii)&nbsp;the average of the highest three annual AIP awards for the
last five years of employment with the Company, whether received or deferred. The benefit accrued under the SERP is payable upon retirement in a lump sum or life annuity with 50% benefit continuation to the participant&#146;s surviving spouse. The
lump sum is equal to the actuarial present value of the joint and survivor </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">65 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">pension earned, reduced by the lump sum value of the benefits to be paid under the tax-qualified pension plan and the value of the executive&#146;s Social
Security benefits. If the executive officer terminates employment after age 55 but before age 60, the benefit is reduced for early retirement at a rate of 5%&nbsp;per year for the period until the executive would have turned 60. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-Height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Lenny contained special provisions relating to the calculation of his
benefit under the SERP in recognition of the impact a mid-career change in jobs has on the long-term accrual of retirement benefits. Under the employment agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Lenny was effectively credited with two years of service for each year of
service from his hire date through his 55</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> birthday. This formula produced a benefit based on 37.5% of his final average compensation at age 55.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West contains special provisions relating to the vesting of his benefit under the SERP. Under the employment
agreement, Mr.&nbsp;West is fully vested in his accrued SERP benefit as of January&nbsp;2, 2008; until January&nbsp;2, 2008, Mr.&nbsp;West was fully vested in his accrued SERP benefit unless he was terminated for cause or resigned without good
reason. If Mr.&nbsp;West terminates employment prior to age 60, the benefit payable upon termination is reduced for early retirement at a rate of 5%&nbsp;per year for the period between termination and attainment of age 60. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist resigned his executive officer position effective December&nbsp;4, 2007 and his active employment ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. As a result of his
termination of employment, Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist forfeited his SERP benefit. As a result of Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist&#146;s resignation, he became a participant in the non-qualified defined benefit Compensation Limit Replacement Plan, or CLRP and his CLRP
benefit of $118,087 was determined as if he had always been eligible to participate in the CLRP. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The CLRP provides each participant the defined benefit he
or she would have earned under our tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan were it not for the legal limitation on compensation used to determine benefits. Upon separation, benefits under the CLRP are payable in a single lump sum or may be
deferred into the Deferred Compensation Plan. A participant is eligible for his or her CLRP benefit after five years of service or attaining age 55 (unless the participant is terminated for cause), and is also eligible upon death; participants who
become disabled are 100% vested in their benefit and continue to accrue additional benefits for up to two additional years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">66 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table and explanatory footnotes provide information regarding the present value of benefits accrued
under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and the SERP for each named executive officer as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. The amounts shown for the SERP reflect the reduction for the present value of the benefits under the tax-qualified
pension plan and Social Security benefits. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Pension Benefits </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="3"><B>2007 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>

</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx66613_21"></A>Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers are eligible to participate in The Hershey Company Deferred
Compensation Plan. The Deferred Compensation Plan is a non-qualified plan that permits participants to defer receipt of compensation otherwise payable to them. The Deferred Compensation Plan is intended to secure the goodwill and loyalty of
participants by enabling them to defer compensation when the participant deems it to be beneficial to do so and by providing a vehicle for the Company to provide on a non-qualified basis contributions which could not be made on the
participant&#146;s behalf to the tax-qualified 401(k) Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers may elect to defer payments to be received as a result of SERP,
CLRP, AIP, PSU and RSU awards (but not stock options). Amounts deferred are credited to the participant&#146;s account under the Plan. Effective January&nbsp;1, 2007, we began crediting the named executive officers&#146; deferred compensation
accounts with the amount of employer matching contributions that exceed the limits established by the Internal Revenue Service for contribution to the 401(k) Plan. These amounts are credited in the first quarter of the year after they are earned. As
shown in the notes to the Summary Compensation Table on page 57, these amounts are included as &#147;All Other Compensation&#148; in the year earned, but are included in Column (c)&nbsp;of the Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation table in the year
credited. Amounts deferred are fully vested and will be paid at a future date or at termination of employment, as the participant may elect. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Payments are
distributed in a lump sum or in annual installments of up to 15 years. All amounts are payable in a lump sum following a change in control. All elections and payments under the Plan are subject to compliance with section 409A of the Internal Revenue
Code which may limit elections and require a delay in payment of benefits in certain circumstances. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">While deferred, amounts are credited with
&#147;earnings&#148; as if they were invested as the participant elects in one or more investment options available under the Plan. The investment options under the Plan consist of investment in shares of our Common Stock or in mutual funds or other
investments available to participants in our 401(k) Plan. The participants&#146; accounts under the Plan will be adjusted from time to time, up or down, depending upon performance of the investment options elected. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">68 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective July&nbsp;16, 2007, Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso was eligible to participate in our non-qualified defined contribution
SERP, or DC SERP, a part of the Deferred Compensation Plan. The DC SERP provides annual allocations to the Deferred Compensation Plan equal to a percentage of compensation determined by the Compensation Committee in its sole discretion. In order to
receive the annual DC SERP allocation, an executive officer must (i)&nbsp;defer in the 401(k) Plan the maximum amount allowed by the Company or IRS and (ii)&nbsp;be employed on the last day of the plan year unless he or she terminates employment
while at least age 55, retires, dies or becomes disabled. After completing five years of service with the Company, an executive officer is vested in 10% increments based on his or her age. An executive age&nbsp;46 with five years of service is 10%
vested and an executive age 55 with five years of service is 100% vested. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso&#146;s annual DC SERP allocation is equal to 12.5% of his base salary and AIP for the calendar year, whether paid or deferred. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table sets forth information relating to the activity in the Deferred Compensation Plan accounts of the named executive officers during 2007 and the
aggregate balance of the accounts as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2007 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="33%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="7%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="7%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="7%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="7%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="7%"></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Name</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="1"><B>Executive&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<BR>Contributions&nbsp;in&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<BR>Last
Fiscal&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<BR>Year<SUP>(1)</SUP>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="1"><B>($)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="1"><B>Registrant&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<BR>Contributions&nbsp;in&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<BR>Last
Fiscal&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<BR>Year&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="1"><B>($)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"

<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">B. H.

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;788,675</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx66613_22"></A>Potential Payments Upon Termination or Change in Control </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have entered into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West and
maintain plans covering our executive officers that will require us to provide incremental compensation in the event of involuntary termination of employment or a change in control. We also entered into agreements with Ms.&nbsp;Arline and
Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist under which we agreed to pay incremental compensation in connection with their departure from the Company. We describe these obligations below. No incremental compensation was paid to Mr.&nbsp;Lenny upon his retirement at year end
2007 under the employment agreement we had entered into with him at the time he joined Hershey in 2001 or otherwise. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Overview </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We entered into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West at the time of his promotion to the position of President in October 2007. The agreement has a term of three
years and renews daily. The agreement provides for Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s employment as our President and effective December&nbsp;1, 2007 as President and Chief Executive Officer, contains provisions relating to his responsibilities, compensation,
confidentiality, non-competition and non-solicitation commitments and agreements, and payments, if any, to be made to him upon termination of employment. Mr.&nbsp;West and our other named executive officers participate in the EBPP, as amended
effective February&nbsp;13, 2008. The plan is intended to help us attract and retain qualified executive employees and maintain a stable work environment by making a provision for the protection of covered executives in connection with a change in
control of Hershey or termination of employment under certain circumstances. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of our named executive officers also has entered into a participation
agreement in connection with the receipt of long-term incentive compensation awards such as stock options and PSUs. The participation agreement obligates the executive officer to not disclose or misuse our confidential and proprietary information.
In addition, any executive officer eligible to receive benefits under the SERP agrees that for three years after termination of employment for any reason, he or she will not join or otherwise become involved with a domestic or worldwide business
that competes in any of our primary product lines. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Termination of employment and a change in control also impact PSUs, RSUs and stock option awards we
have made, as well as benefits payable under our employee benefit plans. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">70 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following narrative takes each termination of employment situation &#150; voluntary resignation, discharge for
cause, death, disability, discharge without cause, and resignation for good reason &#150; and a change in control of the Company, and describes the additional amounts, if any, that the Company would pay or provide to Messrs. West, Alfonso, Bilbrey
and Snyder, or their beneficiaries as a result. The narrative below and the amounts shown reflect certain assumptions we have made in accordance with SEC rules. These assumptions are that the termination of employment or change in control occurred
on December&nbsp;31, 2007 and that the value of a share of our Common Stock on that day was $39.40, the closing price on the New York Stock Exchange on December&nbsp;31, 2007, the last trading day of 2007. We describe the commitments under the
agreements entered into with Ms.&nbsp;Arline and Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist at the end of this section. As noted above, Mr.&nbsp;Lenny did not receive any payments other than vested benefits upon his retirement on December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, in keeping with SEC rules, the following narrative and amounts do not include payments and benefits which are not enhanced by the termination of employment
or change in control. These payments and benefits include: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Benefits accrued under the Company&#146;s broad-based tax-qualified 401(k) Plan and pension plan; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

employees generally; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Stock options which have vested and become exercisable prior to the employment termination or change in control. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The payments and benefits described in the five bullet points above are referred to in the following discussion as the executive officer&#146;s &#147;vested
benefits.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Voluntary Resignation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are not
obligated to pay amounts over and above vested benefits to a named executive officer who voluntarily resigns. Vested stock options may not be exercised after the named executive officer&#146;s resignation date unless the officer is age 55 or older,
as described in <I>Treatment of Stock Options upon Retirement, Death or Disability</I> below. Mr.&nbsp;Lenny&#146;s vested benefits included his SERP benefit, as he was over age 55, and considered a &#147;retiree&#148; for SERP purposes on
December&nbsp;31, 2007. Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s SERP benefit was subject to forfeiture if he voluntarily resigned on December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge for
Cause </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If we terminate a named executive officer&#146;s employment for &#147;cause,&#148; we are not obligated to pay the officer any amounts over and
above the vested benefits. The named executive officer&#146;s right to exercise vested options expires upon discharge for cause, and amounts otherwise payable under the SERP are subject to forfeiture at the Company&#146;s discretion. In general, a
discharge will be for &#147;cause&#148; if the executive has intentionally failed to perform his or her duties or engaged in illegal or gross misconduct that harms the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Death or Disability </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If an executive officer other than Mr.&nbsp;West dies and has not met the vesting requirements
to be eligible to receive a benefit from the SERP, no benefits are paid. Mr.&nbsp;Snyder was fully vested in his SERP benefit as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">71 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A maximum monthly long-term disability benefit of $35,000 is provided for Mr.&nbsp;West and $25,000 for all other named
executive officers in the event of long-term disability. Long-term disability benefits are payable until age 65. Long-term disability benefits are offset by other benefits such as Social Security. The maximum amount of the monthly long-term
disability payments from all sources, assuming long-term disability on December&nbsp;31, 2007, is set forth in the tables below. The additional lump sum SERP amount that would be payable for Messrs. West and Bilbrey at age 65 attributable to vesting
and benefit service credited during the disability period for the SERP, if the executive&#146;s disability started on December&nbsp;31, 2007, is shown on the table below. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso participates in the DC SERP which provides two additional
years of credit after approval for long-term disability and that amount is listed in the table below: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment of Stock Options upon Retirement, Death or Disability </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
Incentive Plan provides that all vested stock options remain exercisable for five years following termination due to retirement after age 55, death or disability, but not beyond the original term of the option. Options that are not vested at the
time of retirement, death or disability will continue to vest throughout the five-year period following retirement, death or disability according to the original vesting schedule established at the grant date. The following table provides the number
of unvested stock options as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 that would have become vested and remained exercisable during the five-year period following death or disability, or retirement, if applicable, on December&nbsp;31, 2007, and the value of those
options based on the excess of the fair market value of our Common Stock on December&nbsp;31, 2007 over the option exercise price. Only Mr.&nbsp;Snyder was retirement eligible on December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P> <P

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment of RSUs upon Retirement, Death or Disability </I> </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Upon retirement any RSUs that are not vested are forfeited. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A prorated
portion of any unvested RSU award vests upon death or disability. The prorated number of RSUs is based upon the number of days from the grant date to the date of death or disability divided by the number of days in the vesting period multiplied by
the number of unvested RSUs. The following table summarizes the unvested RSU awards that would have vested on December&nbsp;31, 2007 if the executive&#146;s employment terminated that day due to death or disability. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Value of shares based on $39.40 closing price for our Common Stock on December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s employment agreement provides for full vesting of the 22,000 RSUs awarded October&nbsp;2, 2007, in the event of his death or disability.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge Not for Cause; Resignation for Good Reason </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West obligates the Company to pay severance benefits if we terminate his employment for reasons other than for &#147;cause&#148; or if Mr.&nbsp;West resigns for &#147;good
reason.&#148; Mr.&nbsp;West will have &#147;good reason&#148; to resign if there is a material breach of the employment agreement by the Company, including a failure to maintain Mr.&nbsp;West in his current positions, adversely changing his
authority or responsibilities, failing to pay or provide agreed-upon compensation and benefits, or giving notice to stop the daily renewal of the term of the employment agreement. Mr.&nbsp;West must give the Company notice and an opportunity to cure
the breach before resigning for &#147;good reason.&#148; The severance benefits payable to Mr.&nbsp;West are a lump sum equal to a pro rata AIP award for the year of termination at target plus two times his annual base salary and target AIP award
for the year of termination, and continuation of health and other benefits for five years, subject to reduction for benefits received from a subsequent employer. In addition, any unvested stock options held by Mr.&nbsp;West will remain outstanding
and continue to vest during the two-year period following termination of employment. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">With respect to the named executive officers other than
Mr.&nbsp;West, under the EBPP, we have agreed to two times salary paid in a lump sum if we terminate the executive officer&#146;s active employment without cause. These benefits are also payable if the executive officer resigns from active
employment for &#147;good reason.&#148; &#147;Good reason&#148; arises under the EBPP if we appoint a new Chief Executive Officer and, during the first two years of his or her tenure, the executive officer&#146;s position, authority, duties or
responsibilities are diminished or base salary is reduced. An applicable two-year period commenced December&nbsp;1, 2007 with Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s appointment as our new Chief Executive Officer. During the leave of absence, the executive
officer&#146;s employment continues, so that he or she will continue to earn, vest or participate in our benefit plans and previously granted stock options and contingent target AIP awards during the leave of absence period. </FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">73 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table summarizes the amount of severance benefits that would be payable to the named executive officer
had his or her employment terminated on December&nbsp;31, 2007, under circumstances entitling the officer to severance benefits as described above: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="92%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="8%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="8%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="15%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="8%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="18%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s employment agreement provides for continuation of medical and dental coverage for a period of five years following discharge not for cause or resignation for
good reason. The amount shown above includes that cost and the value of vision coverage for a period of two years. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, all stock
options outstanding at the time of termination of active employment will remain outstanding and continue to vest as if the executive officer&#146;s employment continued during the two-year leave of absence. The executive officer will not be entitled
to receive base salary, new stock option, contingent target PSU or RSU awards or other awards during the leave of absence. Information with respect to stock options held by each executive officer as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 appears in the
Outstanding Equity Awards table. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Change in Control </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Special provisions apply if a change in control occurs. In general, a change in control will occur if the Milton Hershey School Trust no longer owns voting control of the Company and another person or group acquires 25% or more of the
combined voting power of our voting stock, there is an unwelcome change in a majority of the members of our Board, or, if after our stockholders approve a merger or similar business transaction or a sale of substantially all of our assets, the
Milton Hershey School Trust does not own voting control of the merged or acquiring company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West provides that he
is entitled to the benefits of the EBPP if a change in control occurs. The EBPP provides the vesting and payment of the following benefits upon a change in control to each of the named executive officers: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">An AIP payment for the year of the change in control at the greater of target or the estimated payment based on actual performance to the date of the change in

the change in control, with each PSU valued at the highest closing price for our Common Stock during the 60 days prior to the change in control; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects the value of unvested RSUs that would vest upon a change in control based on the market value of our Common Stock of $39.40 on December&nbsp;31, 2007. Information regarding
unvested RSUs as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 can be found in the Outstanding Equity Awards table. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge Not for Cause or Resignation
for Good Reason after Change in Control </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If the named executive officer&#146;s employment is terminated by the Company without cause or by the
executive for good reason within two years after the change in control, we pay severance benefits to assist the executive in transitioning to new employment. &#147;Good reason&#148; for this purpose means diminution of the executive&#146;s position,
authority, duties or responsibilities; a reduction in base salary; the requirement that the executive engage in substantially greater business travel; failure to pay current compensation or to continue in effect short- and long-term compensation and
employee and retirement benefits; or the failure to fund a grantor trust to support payment of amounts under the EBPP. The severance benefits under the EBPP for termination after a change in control in 2007 consist of: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; padding-bottom:3px; margin-top:-2px" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"> <P STYLE="line-Height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="line-height:95%; vertical-align:top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A lump sum cash payment equal to three (or, if less, the number of full and fractional years from the date of
termination to the executive&#146;s 65</FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>th</SUP></FONT><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> birthday, but not less than one) times the executive&#146;s salary and the highest AIP payment earned
during the three years preceding the year of the change in control (but not less than the AIP target for the year of the change in control); </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">75 </FONT></P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Continuation of medical and other benefits for 36 months (or if less, the number of months until the executive attains age 65, but not less than 12 months), or
payment of the value of such benefits if continuation is not permitted under the terms of the applicable plan; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The EBPP also provides for a gross-up payment should the executive be subject to the excise tax on golden parachutes due to the receipt of severance benefits or as a result of the payment or vesting of stock options
upon the change in control. The table below summarizes the severance payments, the tax gross-up payment and all other amounts that would have vested and become payable if a change in control occurred and the executive&#146;s employment terminated on
December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As discussed on page 53 of the Compensation Discussion and Analysis, on February&nbsp;13, 2008 the Board reduced the change in
control severance benefits under the EBPP by one-third. The Board and Mr. West also agreed to amend Mr. West&#146;s employment agreement to conform to this change with respect to the Lump Sum Cash Severance Payment. In accordance with SEC rules the

</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s employment agreement provides for continuation of medical and dental coverage for a period of five years following termination due to change in control. The
amount shown above includes that cost and the value of life insurance and vision coverage for a period of three years. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Payments Made
Relating to Individual Agreements </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;16, 2007, we announced that Marcella K. Arline, Senior Vice President, Chief People Officer,
intended to retire at the end of 2007.&nbsp;Ms. Arline first considered retirement under the Company&#146;s 2005 Early Retirement Program (&#147;ERP&#148;), but was asked at that time by the Chair of the Committee to stay on with the
Company.&nbsp;The Chair of the Committee informed Ms.&nbsp;Arline that if she did not retire under the ERP, the Committee would consider providing benefits to her in addition to those to which she would be entitled under the applicable benefit plans
upon her </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">76 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">actual retirement to compensate her for foregone benefits under the ERP.&nbsp;Ms. Arline elected not to retire at that time. Prior to a meeting of the
Committee on October&nbsp;1, 2007, Ms.&nbsp;Arline informed the Committee Chair that she was again considering retirement.&nbsp;At that meeting, the Committee considered, and ultimately decided to provide the additional benefits to Ms.&nbsp;Arline
should she elect to retire at the end of 2007.&nbsp;A Retirement Agreement and General Release, providing for the payment in a lump sum of $983,121 to approximate the additional benefits she would have received had she retired under the ERP, was
prepared and given to Ms.&nbsp;Arline to execute if and when she made a final retirement decision.&nbsp;Ms. Arline indicated her intention to retire by signing and delivering the agreement to the Company on November&nbsp;11, 2007. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;30, 2007, we announced that Thomas K. Hernquist, Senior Vice President, Global Chief Growth Officer, resigned from the Company.&nbsp;Mr.
Hernquist&#146;s tenure as an elected officer of the Company ended on December&nbsp;4, 2007, and his last day of active employment was December&nbsp;31, 2007. In connection with his resignation, Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist entered into a Confidential
Agreement and General Release pursuant to which he will receive benefits under the Company&#146;s EBPP and provide, through December&nbsp;31, 2008, certain consultation and transition assistance if and as reasonably requested by the
Company.&nbsp;The agreement also contains covenants regarding confidentiality and non-competition. Per the terms of the EBPP, Mr.&nbsp;Hernquist received a lump sum payment in the amount of $840,000. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx66613_23"></A>PROPOSAL NO. 3 &#150; STOCKHOLDER PROPOSAL </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is being proposed? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">William C. Thompson, Jr., Comptroller, City of New York, on behalf of the Boards of Trustees of the New York City Pension Funds, advised the Company that he or his
representative intends to present the following stockholder proposal at the annual meeting. The address and share ownership of the proponent will be furnished to any stockholder upon request. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Text of the Stockholder Proposal </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WHEREAS,</B> over 70% of the
world&#146;s cocoa originates in West Africa with most of that crop coming from the nations of Ghana and the Ivory Coast, and </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WHEREAS,</B> media
reports in 2000 and 2001 in the UK and U.S. describing child trafficking and enslavement in West Africa cocoa farms led to the establishment of an industry &#150; wide Cocoa Protocol in 2001
(www.cocoaverification.org/en/archives/HarkinEngelProtocol.pdf), and </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>WHEREAS,</B> despite public commitments to eliminate the worst forms of child
labor in West Africa by July 2005, the cocoa industry largely failed to meet that commitment and the child labor situation remained virtually unchanged, and </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>WHEREAS, </B>in 2005, the initiators of the protocol, Senator Tom Harkin (D-IA) and Congressman Elliot Engel (D-NY) negotiated an extension of deadline under which the industry pledged to have an anti-forced labor compliance and
monitoring system in place by July 2008, </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>THEREFORE,</B> be it resolved that shareholders request the Board of Directors to review and report on
progress towards implementation of the 2001 Cocoa Protocol against forced child labor. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This report should contain information on the company&#146;s
efforts to establish transparency in their cocoa supply chains, and steps the company is taking to train its buyers and quality control specialists on what practices constitute violations of local and international standards and on methodologies to
independently verify evidence provided by farmers and local communities. </FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">77 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is the view of the Board of Directors regarding this proposal? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Board of Directors unanimously opposes this proposal. The Hershey Company is committed to improving the well-being of cocoa farmers and their families and to
ensuring that this important crop is grown responsibly. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2001, in response to reports about abusive child labor practices in West African cocoa growing
regions, The Hershey Company and other global chocolate and cocoa industry members joined a congressionally sponsored Protocol designed to address this problem. Since that time, significant progress has been achieved in implementing an effective,
verifiable system of certification designed to clearly identify the nature and extent of labor problems in the Ivory Coast and Ghana, and to ensure that effective remediation steps are taken where such problems exist. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Today, working conditions in West Africa&#146;s cocoa sector are better understood, thanks to an independent survey conducted across the region in 2002 and to two
groundbreaking certification pilot studies carried out in the Ivory Coast and Ghana during 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">These studies show that children do help their families
on the nearly two&nbsp;million small farms growing cocoa in the region. Instances of child trafficking, an illegal activity violating national and international laws, have been found. However, the most significant challenges affecting families on
these small farms concern traditional attitudes toward child work and the lack of access to quality education, both academic and vocational. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Hershey
Company is playing a leadership role in helping to address these issues. Through the World Cocoa Foundation, Hershey helps sponsor programs that are measurably improving the economic and social well-being of cocoa farming families. The Sustainable
Tree Crops Program, a partnership of industry and USAID, is significantly raising participating farmer productivity and incomes. The International Cocoa Initiative, of which Hershey is a member, is working in the Ivory Coast and Ghana to raise
community awareness regarding farm activities inappropriate for children and the importance of children attending school. In partnership with the International Foundation for Education&nbsp;&amp; Self-Help (IFESH), Hershey supports teacher training
in these two countries, helping address the need for more and better qualified teachers in rural communities. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">These programs are part of a broad effort by
industry, the governments of the Ivory Coast and Ghana, international donors, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) to ensure that cocoa is grown responsibly. These efforts and their progress in helping address the child labor problem have been
the subject of transparent, public reporting by the global chocolate and cocoa industry over the past three years. The Payson Center for International Development of Tulane University, as part of a congressionally funded mandate, also has reported
extensively on this subject and will continue to do so over the next two years. The Hershey Company, as a leader in this area, also has publicly detailed its efforts to ensure that the cocoa it uses in the production of its products is grown without
abusive child labor or forced adult labor. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Especially important in this regard is the successful implementation of a credible, verifiable certification
system in the Ivory Coast and Ghana. Both countries have publicly reported the results of groundbreaking pilot studies conducted during 2007, showing the extent and nature of child labor problems where they exist in the cocoa sector and detailing
remediation efforts. The Ivory Coast and Ghana currently are implementing this certification system across 50% of their respective cocoa-growing areas, a key Protocol requirement. The results of these studies, which will be expanded annually to
cover a greater percentage of each country&#146;s cocoa growing region, are to be made publicly available by July 2008. An independent Verification Board, convened by social audit firm Verite, currently is at work and will publicly report on an
ongoing basis regarding the effectiveness and accuracy of these certification studies. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">78 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The report requested by the proponent is unnecessary. Hershey&#146;s efforts in this area, as well as those of
industry, government, international donors and NGOs are well documented. Additional reporting would be duplicative and of no incremental value to the Board, our stockholders or other stakeholders. For all of the above reasons, the Board unanimously
opposes this proposal. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>How many votes will be required to approve Proposal No.&nbsp;3? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Stockholders will approve the proposal if the holders of record of the Common Stock and Class B Common Stock present (in person or by proxy) at the annual meeting cast
more votes for the proposal than against the proposal. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is the Board&#146;s recommendation for voting on Proposal No.&nbsp;3? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="70%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="100%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px; padding-right:8px"> <P STYLE="font-size:10px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">The Board of Directors unanimously recommends that stockholders</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" align="left">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">vote <B>AGAINST</B> Proposal No.&nbsp;3.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:16px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" align="left">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx66613_24"></A>PROPOSAL NO. 4 &#150; STOCKHOLDER PROPOSAL </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is being proposed? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">John C. Harrington, Treasurer of Global Exchange, advised the Company that he or his representative intends to present the following stockholder proposal at the annual
meeting. The address and share ownership of the proponent will be furnished to any stockholder upon request. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Text of the Stockholder Proposal
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>RESOLVED:</B> &nbsp;&nbsp;To amend the Bylaws, by inserting the following new section at the end of Article IV: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Section&nbsp;4. Committee on Human Rights. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">There is established a Board
Committee on Human Rights, which is created and authorized to review the implications of company policies, above and beyond matters of legal compliance, for the human rights of individuals in the US and worldwide. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Board of Directors is authorized in its discretion consistent with these Bylaws, the Articles of Incorporation, and applicable law to (1)&nbsp;select the members of
the Board Committee on Human Rights, (2)&nbsp;provide said committee with funds for operating expenses, (3)&nbsp;adopt regulations or guidelines to govern said Committee&#146;s operations, (4)&nbsp;empower said Committee to solicit public input and
to issue periodic reports to shareholders and the public, at reasonable expense and excluding confidential information, including but not limited to an annual report on the implications of company policies, above and beyond matters of legal
compliance, for the human rights of individuals in the US and worldwide, and (5)&nbsp;any other measures within the Board&#146;s discretion consistent with these Bylaws and applicable law. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Nothing herein shall restrict the power of the Board of Directors to manage the business and affairs of the company. The Board Committee on Human Rights shall not incur
any costs to the company except as authorized by the Board of Directors. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>SUPPORTING STATEMENT </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The proposed Bylaw would establish a Board Committee on Human Rights which would review and make policy recommendations regarding human rights issues raised by the
company&#146;s </FONT>
</P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">79 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">activities and policies. We believe the proposed Board Committee on Human Rights could be an effective mechanism for addressing the human rights implications
of the company&#146;s activities and policies as they emerge anywhere in the world. In defining &#147;human rights,&#148; proponents suggest that the committee could use the Universal Declaration of Human Rights as nonbinding benchmark or reference
documents. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is the view of the Board of Directors regarding this proposal? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Hershey Company has a long tradition of supporting human rights. This tradition is evident in our dealings with employees, suppliers, customers and consumers, as well as with the communities in which we do
business. Our Statement of Corporate Philosophy is founded on four fundamental precepts, the first of which is to maintain and enforce high standards of ethical conduct. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">To this end, the Company has adopted and adheres strictly to a written Code of Ethical Business Conduct. The Code sets minimum standards of conduct for our directors, officers and employees worldwide. The Code makes
clear that compliance with the law is mandatory, that employees are entitled to fair and equitable treatment and to a safe and healthy workplace, that protection of the environment is a priority and that those with whom we do business will be
treated fairly, without deceit or manipulation. The Ethical Business Practices Committee, composed of senior executives of the Company and chaired by our General Counsel, monitors and enforces the Code under the oversight of the Audit Committee of
the Board of Directors. The Audit Committee receives regular reports from the General Counsel&#146;s office on communication, monitoring, training and compliance activities relating to the Code. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition to its enforcement of the Code, in 2000 the Company endorsed the Global Sullivan Principles of Social Responsibility, a voluntary code of conduct established
by the late Reverend Leon&nbsp;H. Sullivan to provide international businesses like Hershey with a framework for working toward human rights, social justice and economic opportunity. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2007, The Hershey Company adopted a best-practice Supplier Code of Conduct to ensure, among other things, that its vendors and suppliers understand and support the Company&#146;s commitment to global human rights.
This Code expressly states Hershey&#146;s commitment to providing a workplace built on trust, honesty, fair treatment, and respect for basic human values, as well as its expectation that the Company&#146;s direct suppliers abide by all national and
local laws applicable to the workplace. The Supplier Code of Conduct, currently being rolled out to all of the Company&#146;s direct suppliers, references those Conventions of the International Labor Organization (ILO) of the UN concerning the
&#147;worst forms of child labor,&#148; forced labor and nondiscrimination, as well as freedom of association and wages and hours of work for hourly workers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Also in 2007, The Hershey Company formally established a Corporate Social Responsibility function to ensure, among other things, that human rights and related corporate citizenship issues receive the necessary attention and support within
the Company as well as within the confectionery industry. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Hershey Company actively supports organizations working to address human rights issues in
the U.S. and internationally. These organizations include, among others, the NAACP, the Leon H. Sullivan Foundation, the International Cocoa Initiative Foundation, the International Foundation for Education&nbsp;&amp; Self-Help, the New York Society
for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, and the Human Rights Campaign. In addition, the Company has been a leader in working to ensure that cocoa is grown responsibly, without the worst forms of child labor or forced adult labor. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have made the protection of human rights a priority for our business. The establishment of a Board Committee on Human Rights would neither bring greater attention to
this important issue </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">80 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">nor enhance the efforts we currently are making in this regard. For all these reasons, the Board does not believe that adoption of this proposal is necessary
or in furtherance of the best interests of Hershey stockholders. Accordingly, we unanimously oppose the proposal. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>How many votes will be required to
approve Proposal No.&nbsp;4? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Stockholders will approve the proposal if the holders of record of the Common Stock and Class B Common Stock present (in
person or by proxy) at the annual meeting cast more votes for the proposal than against the proposal. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is the Board&#146;s recommendation for
voting on Proposal No.&nbsp;4? </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="70%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="100%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px; padding-right:8px"> <P STYLE="font-size:10px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">The Board of Directors unanimously recommends that stockholders</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" align="left">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">vote <B>AGAINST</B> Proposal No.&nbsp;4.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:16px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px" align="left">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx66613_25"></A>SECTION 16(a) BENEFICIAL OWNERSHIP REPORTING COMPLIANCE </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is section 16(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934? </B>
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Section&nbsp;16(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, requires our directors, executive officers and persons owning more than 10% of our
outstanding Common Stock or Class B Common Stock to file reports with the SEC showing their ownership and changes in ownership of Hershey securities. Based solely on our examination of these reports and on written representations provided to us, it
is our opinion that all reports for 2007 have been timely filed. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="tx66613_26"></A>CERTAIN TRANSACTIONS AND RELATIONSHIPS </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>What is being disclosed in this section? </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">SEC regulations require that we disclose any transaction, or series of similar transactions, since the beginning of 2007, or any contemplated transactions, in which the
Company was or is to be a participant, in which the amount involved exceeds $120,000 and in which any of the following persons had or will have a direct or indirect material interest: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our directors or nominees for director; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
